title-group.article-title: Prevalence of opioid and nonopioid pain management therapies among Medicare beneficiaries with musculoskeletal pain conditions from 2016 to 2019

fn.p: Conflict of interest: No conflict declared

sec.title: Introduction:
sec.p: Pain treatment guidelines prioritize nonopioid therapies over opioid medications to prevent opioid-related harms. We examined trends in receipt and intensity of nonpharmacologic, nonopioid medication, and opioid therapies among Medicare beneficiaries.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Using a 20% national random sample of Medicare data from 2016-2019, we identified fee-for-service beneficiaries with ≥2 diagnoses of back, neck, fibromyalgia, or osteoarthritis/joint pain annually. We excluded beneficiaries with cancer. We calculated annual proportions of beneficiaries who received physical therapy (PT), chiropractic care, gabapentin, and opioids, overall and in demographic, geographic, and clinical subgroups. We estimated the intensity of therapies using the annual number of visits/fills, prescription days’ supply, and opioid dose.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: During 2016-2019, PT receipt increased (22.8% to 25.5%) and the mean number of visits among users went from 12 to 13. Chiropractic receipt (~18%) and mean visits (~10) remained unchanged. The prevalence of gabapentin receipt was stable at ~22% and the mean number of fills was unchanged though gabapentin days increased slightly. Opioid prescribing decreased (56.7% to 46.5%) and reductions in opioid dose and duration were observed. Opioid receipt was high among beneficiaries who were under 65 years, American Indian/Alaska Native, Black/African American, or had OUD, in whom nonpharmacologic therapies were also received the least.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Utilization of nonopioid therapies lagged opioids among Medicare beneficiaries with musculoskeletal pain, with limited changes from 2016-2019. As opioid prescribing declines and alternative pain therapy receipt remains low, there are potential increasing risks of pain going untreated or undertreated and individuals seeking illicit opioids to alleviate their pain.
